Ifuu Review | Bon Appetit









































Close Menu IconLoginRecipesCookingCultureShoppingRestaurantsBA MarketVideosPodcastSubscribe to our newsletterSign UpPrivacy and user agreementMain Navigation IconBA LogoBon appetitLogintokyoIfuuCome to this izayaka for the sake, stay for the seasonal fish.FacebookPinterestTwitterEmailPhoto by Xavier Girard LachaîneGO HERE: for an elegant izakaya where seasonality is king and dishes are prepared with a level of craft that transcends any normal pub food. While a cold draft beer is a fine choice, cooking of this caliber really demands good sake. Plus, you get to pick your own tiny cup to drink from, which is even better than choosing your favorite Monopoly piece.ORDER THE: sashimi to start, picking at least a few from the daily specials, which feature peak ingredients. The yakitori is also a popular option. But only amateurs would tank up on proteins and cheat themselves out of the rice, which is the best—and last—part of the meal: One of Ifuu’s most famous specialties is a giant donabe of hot rice that has been steamed with a flotilla of uni on top.THE VIBE IS: spare but warm, like eating dinner in a Muji advertisement. The bottom floor is a brightly lit room where the chefs bustle about the open kitchen and the bulk of the seating is at a counter. There are tables for bigger groups upstairs, though you’ll still want to call ahead if you have a party of more than four.PRACTICAL STUFF: Open Monday through Saturday from 5:30 p.m. to midnight. Closed on Sundays and some holidays. Little English is spoken by the staff, but the menu will list the regular offerings in English. Specials are not usually translated, but try your best to ask for recommendations. Reservations recommended. The nearest subway station is Naka-Meguro.Photo by Xavier Girard LachaîneThe peak-season sashimi is listed on the daily specials menu.
Photo by Xavier Girard LachaîneYou can’t go wrong with the yakitori.
